facts.text: Writ Petition No. 17 of 1965 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 17 of 1965. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Petitioner is a trader at Meerut.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. The petitioner. who is a trader at Meerut was ordered by the Income-tax Officer,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, D-Ward, Meerut ordered petitioner to pay Rs. 1,800 as annuity deposit under Chapter XXII-A of Income-tax Act, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: who is a trader at Meerut was ordered by the Income-tax Officer, D-Ward, Meerut, to pay Rs. 1,800/- as annuity deposit under Ch. XXII-A of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

facts.text: Petitioner filed petition challenging validity of the demand notice for annuity deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has filed this petition challenging the validity of the demand on the plea that Ch. XXII-A of the Income-tax Act is unconstitutional and is otherwise violative of the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Indian Income-tax Act, 1961 enacted by Parliament to consolidate and amend law relating to income-tax and super-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Income-tax Act 43 of 1961 was enacted by the Parliament to companysolidate and amend the law relating to income-tax and super-tax.

facts.text: Income-tax Act, 1961 came into force on April 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on April 1, 1962.

facts.text: Finance Act, 1964 enacted to give effect to financial proposals for 1964-65.

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament enacted Finance Act 5 of 1964 to give effect to the financial proposals of the Central Government for the financial year 1964-65,

facts.text: Section 31 of Finance Act, 1964 provided for annuity deposit for assessment year commencing April 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: and by S. 3   1   of that Act it was provided Save as otherwise provided in Chapter XXII-A of the Income-tax Act, annuity deposit for the assessment year companymencing on the 1st day of April, 1964

facts.text: Section 44 of Finance Act, 1964 introduced Chapter XXII-A (sections 280-A to 280-X) into Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 44 of the Finance Act, Ch. XXII-A relating to annuity deposits companytaining ss.280-A to 280-X was introduced into the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Annuity deposits required from specified taxpayers with total income exceeding Rs. 15,000 for assessment years from 1964-65.

anchor.surface_text: By that chapter taxpayers of certain categories are required to make annuity deposits for every assessment year companymencing from the assessment year 1964-65.

facts.text: Rates of annuity deposits prescribed in Second Schedule to Finance Act, rising from 5% to 12.5% on adjusted total income.

anchor.surface_text: By the Second Schedule to the Finance Act, rates of annuity deposits are prescribed. The deposit has to be made by the specified categories of taxpayers, having a total income exceeding Rs. 15,000 at the prescribed percentages rising from 5 to 12 1/2

facts.text: Specified categories include resident Indian citizens, HUFs, unregistered firms, AOPs, but exclude companies, co-operative societies, corporations established by Acts.

anchor.surface_text: A taxpayer who is a resident and falls within any of the following categories is liable to make the annuity deposit an individual, who is a citizen of India, a Hindu undivided family, an unregistered firm, an association of persons or a body of individuals, whether incorporated or number  other than a companypany or a companyperative society , and an artificial juridical person referred to in sub- clause  vii  of cl.  31  of S. 2 of the Income-tax Act  other than a companyporation established by a Central, State or Provincial Act .

facts.text: Taxpayer may opt out of annuity deposit by notice to ITO before June 30 of assessment year, option irrevocable.

anchor.surface_text: But a taxpayer who is required by s. 280-A, to make an annuity deposit may exercise his option number to make it, by a numberice in writing to the Income-tax Officer before the 30th of June of the assessment year. The option once exercised is irrevocable,

facts.text: If opt out, pay additional income-tax equal to 50% of amount saved by not making deposit, except individuals over 70 years old.

anchor.surface_text: The taxpayer who exercises the option has to pay beside the income-tax payable on his total income, additional income-tax which is equal to half of the amount which he saves by number making the deposit. But an individual who on the last day of the relevant previous year is more than seventy years of age is exempt

facts.text: Annuity deposit repayable in ten annual equated instalments of principal and interest.

anchor.surface_text: The annuity deposit is repayable in ten annual equated instalments of principal and interest at such rates as may be prescribed.

facts.text: Annuity deposit amount deductible in computing total income for that year.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of annuity deposit payable by a taxpayer in any year is admissible as a deduction in companyputing his total income charged to tax for that year.

facts.text: Petitioner contends Chapter XXII-A invalid as Parliament lacked competence, being borrowing provision.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner submits that the scheme of annuity deposit incorporated in Ch. XXII-A is invalid because  a  the Parliament had numbercompetence to incorporate in the Indian Income-tax Act, a provision which was substantially one relating to borrowings by the Central Government from a class of taxpayers

facts.text: Petitioner contends Chapter XXII-A is colourable exercise of legislative power and expropriatory.

anchor.surface_text: b  the provisions companytained in Ch. XXII-A are enacted in companyourable exercise of legislative power, and that in any event they are so harsh and unconscionable that they may be regarded as expropriatory

facts.text: Petitioner contends sections 280 and Schedule II discriminatory, infringe Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: c  the provisions of s. 280 and Sch. II are discriminatory and infringe the fundamental freedom under Art. 14 of equality before the law.

facts.text: Court held no substance in petitioner's contentions and dismissed petition with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is numbersubstance in any of the companytentions. ... The petition fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Hidayatullah J. delivered separate opinion agreeing to dismiss petition.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. I agree that this petition should be dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation to the Second Schedule, the expression total income under the Schedule means the total income computed in the manner laid down in the Income-tax Act without making any allowance under s. 280-O
Section 280B defines, amongst other expressions, adjusted total income, a percentage of which is by the Second Schedule liable to be deposited as annuity deposit.

issues.text: Whether the Parliament had competence to incorporate in the Indian Income-tax Act, a provision which was substantially one relating to borrowings by the Central Government from a class of taxpayers

anchor.surface_text: a  the Parliament had numbercompetence to incorporate in the Indian Income-tax Act, a provision which was substantially one relating to borrowings by the Central Government from a class of taxpayers  b  the provisions companytained

anchor.surface_text: the provisions contained in Ch. XXII-A are enacted in colourable exercise of legislative power, and that in any event they are so harsh and unconscionable that they may be regarded as expropriatory

anchor.surface_text: , and that in any event they are so harsh and unconscionable that they may be regarded as expropriatory and on that account number within the legislative companypetence of the Parliament and  c  the provisions

issues.text: Whether the pith and substance of Ch. XXII-A relates to taxes on income under Entry 82 List I or requires recourse to residuary Entry 97

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament has by Art. 246 read with Entry 82 in List I of the Seventh Schedule power to levy taxes on income other than agricultural income.... It is always necessary to examine the pith and substance of any law impugned on the ground of want of legislative competence

arguments.claim: Parliament had no competence to incorporate annuity deposit provisions in the Income-tax Act as it substantially relates to borrowings by the Central Government from a class of taxpayers

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner submits that the scheme of annuity deposit incorporated in Ch. XXII-A is invalid because  a  the Parliament had numbercompetence to incorporate in the Indian Income-tax Act, a provision which was substantially one relating to borrowings by the Central Government from a class of taxpayers

court_response_anchor.surface_text: fundamental rights, as was assumed in certain earlier decisions Ramjilal v. Income- tax Officer 1  Laxmanappa Hanumantappa v. Union of India 2  and t

arguments.court_reasoning: Pith and substance is taxes on income under Entry 82 List I; closely integrated with income-tax machinery; no prohibition on combining with Entry 97 in one Act

arguments.claim: Provisions in Ch. XXII-A enacted in colourable exercise of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: b  the provisions contained in Ch. XXII-A are enacted in colourable exercise of legislative power, and that in any event they are so harsh and unconscionable that they may be regarded as expropriatory

court_response_anchor.surface_text: number-corporate income- tax has number been adopted, and the demand of deposit is made at a steeply rising percentage on the adjusted total income. B

arguments.court_reasoning: Doctrine of colourable legislation inapplicable as Parliament has direct power under relevant entries; cites K.C. Gajapati Narayan Deo explaining no question of bona fides but transgression of powers, not present here

arguments.claim: Provisions of Ch. XXII-A so harsh, unconscionable and expropriatory as to be beyond legislative competence

anchor.surface_text: the provisions contained in Ch. XXII-A are enacted in colourable exercise of legislative power, and that in any event they are so harsh and unconscionable that they may be regarded as expropriatory and on that account number within the legislative competence of the Parliament

court_response_anchor.surface_text: at the latter should be exempted from payment of additional tax. Every taxpayer who is otherwise required to make a deposit is permitted to declare hi

arguments.court_reasoning: Taxing statutes not challengeable merely for being harsh or excessive; subject to Art. 13 but only if expropriatory or no procedure; cites Thathunni Moopil Nair and others

arguments.claim: Provisions of s. 280 and Sch. II discriminatory and infringe Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: c  the provisions of s. 280 and Sch. II are discriminatory and infringe the fundamental freedom under Art. 14 of equality before the law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasonable classification with rational nexus: income >15k, progressive rates, age exemption for 70+ have real distinction related to mobilisation of savings and curbing inflation

arguments.claim: Parliament has power under Art. 246 and Entry 82 List I to levy taxes on income including annuity deposits

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament has by Art. 246 read with Entry 82 in List I of the Seventh Schedule power to levy taxes on income other than agricultural income. The Indian Income-tax Act, 1961 and the provisions of the annual Finance Acts

arguments.claim: Even if annuity deposit is borrowing, power exists under Entry 97 List I residuary

anchor.surface_text: Granting that the scheme of Ch. XXII-A is for borrowing money by the Central Government from the taxpayers in the higher income group at the rates prescribed, which is repayable in instalments, power to legislate in that behalf is still within the competence of the Parliament by virtue of Entry 97 of List I of the Seventh Schedule.

arguments.claim: No constitutional prohibition against incorporating provisions under multiple entries including residuary in single statute like Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioner does not contend that power to collect annuity deposit is outside the Parliaments competence he merely urges that the Parliament could not incorporate the provisions relatable to the exercise of the power of borrowing exercisable under Entry 97 in a legislation which was exclusively enacted in exercise of the powers under Entry 82. But if the Parliament has the power to legislate for collecting annuity deposits from taxpayers, there is nothing in the Constitution which disentitles the Parliament as a matter of legislative arrangement to incorporate the provisions relating to borrowing from taxpayers in the Income-tax Act or any other statute.

arguments.claim: Incorporation in Income-tax Act convenient as closely related, uses same assessment and recovery machinery

anchor.surface_text: The power of assessment, and collection of annuity deposit is entrusted to Income-tax Officers, and the machinery of the Income-tax Act is utilised for that purpose. The annuity deposit is based on the total income of the taxpayer if the taxpayer pays the deposit he is entitled to deduction of the amount in the computation of income tax, and if he exercises the option not to pay the deposit, he is rendered liable to pay additional income-tax.

arguments.claim: Ch. XXII-A not colourable legislation as per doctrine explained in K.C. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. State of Orissa

anchor.surface_text: The argument that Ch. XXII-A is - a colourable exercise of legislative power has no substance. As pointed out by this Court in K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo and others v. The State of Orissa the doctrine of colourable legislation does not involve any question of bona fides and mala fides on the part of the legislature.

arguments.claim: Taxing statute cannot be challenged merely for being harsh or excessive, only if expropriatory or lacking procedure

anchor.surface_text: Exercise of the taxing power of the State has undoubtedly to be tested in the light of the fundamental freedoms guaranteed by Ch. III of the Constitution. ... But it is not settled by decisions of this Court e.g. Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair, v. The State of Kerala and Another that a taxing statute is subject to the conditions laid down in Art. 13 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification based on real distinction with rational relation to object

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 of the Constitution guarantees equality before the law, and equal protection of the laws. But thereby the power of the Legislature to make a reasonable classification of persons, objects or transactions for attaining certain objectives is not excluded. If a classification is based on some real and substantial distinction, bearing a just and reasonable relation to the objects sought to be achieved, it is valid.

arguments.claim: Exemption for income below Rs. 15,000 reasonable with nexus to mobilisation of savings and curbing inflation

anchor.surface_text: What is sought to be achieved by the Act is the twin objective of mobilisation of private savings for public purposes and imposing curbs on the inflationary trends in the economy of our country. To secure this purpose, provision has been made to collect what may reasonably be assumed to be surplus income or private savings so as to make them available for national development.

arguments.claim: Progressive rates and slab system reasonable for higher incomes

anchor.surface_text: The view of the Legislature that in the higher income groups there would be larger savings cannot also be said to be unreasonable. It is true that a slab system in vogue for the computation of non-corporate income-tax has not been adopted, and the demand of deposit is made at a steeply rising percentage on the adjusted total income. But that by itself is not a ground for regarding the levy as unreasonable.

arguments.claim: Scheme not compulsory due to option to opt out and pay additional tax instead

anchor.surface_text: Again it may be noticed that the scheme for the annuity deposits is in a sense not compulsory. By making a declaration it is open to an assessee not to make the contribution as required by the Act. He may elect not to make the deposit, and pay income-tax on his total income.

arguments.claim: Exemption from additional tax for individuals over 70 years reasonable classification

anchor.surface_text: There is undoubtedly a distinction made between persons who are below the age of seventy years on the last day of the previous year, and those who have attained that age the former on exercising the option not to pay annuity deposits will have to pay tax on the total income and additional income-tax, the latter will only pay tax on total income but not additional income-tax.

arguments.claim: Pith and substance of annuity deposit provisions is taxes on income under Entry 82, alternative to full tax

anchor.surface_text: It is always necessary to examine the pith and substance of any law impugned on the ground of want of legislative competence with a view to ascertaining the precise entry in which it can come. The entries in the three Lists were intended to be exhaustive and it would be a very remote chance that some entry would not suit the legislation which is impugned.

arguments.claim: Annuity deposit not borrowing under Art. 292 as it is legislative tax relief scheme, not executive action on Consolidated Fund

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that this is a case of borrowing which is defined in Art. 366(4) to include the raising of money by the grant of annuities, and loan is also required to be construed accordingly. ... Borrowing under that Article is by executive action and it is on the security of the Consolidated Fund of India.

arguments.claim: Entry 97 residuary is last resort, not to avoid determining precise entry; first examine if covered by specific entry like 82

anchor.surface_text: I agree generally with the reasons given by my brother Shah, but I wish to say that I do not rest my decision on entry No. 97 of List I of the Seventh Schedule. ... That entry, no doubt, confers residuary powers of legislation or taxation but it is not an entry to avoid a discussion as to the nature of a law or of a tax with a view to determining the precise entry under which it can come.

arguments.claim: Provisions not colourable or discriminatory as apply to upper income groups, defer tax on part of income

anchor.surface_text: The provisions are neither colourable nor discriminatory. They apply to upper income groups and this does not lead to discrimination. They are not colourable because, though called annuity deposits, they only defer payment of tax on a part of the assessable income and the name does not matter at all.

holdings.text: Chapter XXII-A of the Income-tax Act is within the legislative competence of Parliament under Entry 82 List I (taxes on income) and, even if regarded as borrowing, under Entry 97 List I.

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament has by Art. 246 read with Entry 82 in List I of the Seventh Schedule power to levy taxes on income other than agricultural income. The Indian Income-tax Act, 1961 and the provisions of the annual Finance Acts

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance relates to taxes on income; integrated with income-tax assessment and recovery machinery; no bar to combining powers under multiple entries in one Act.

holdings.text: There is no prohibition against Parliament incorporating in a single statute provisions relatable to powers under multiple entries including residuary Entry 97.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioner does not contend that power to collect annuity deposit is outside the Parliaments competence he merely urges that the Parliament could not incorporate the provisions relatable to the exercise of the power of borrowing exercisable under Entry 97

holdings.reasoning_summary: Convenience of legislative arrangement; shared machinery with income-tax justifies inclusion in IT Act.

holdings.text: Chapter XXII-A is not a colourable exercise of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that Ch. XXII-A is - a colourable exercise of legislative power has no substance. As pointed out by this Court in K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo and others v. The State of Orissa the doctrine of colourable legislation does not involve any question of bona fides

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament has direct power under relevant entries; doctrine applies only to disguised transgression of powers, citing precedent.

holdings.text: Provisions of Chapter XXII-A are not so harsh, unconscionable or expropriatory as to be beyond legislative competence.

anchor.surface_text: Exercise of the taxing power of the State has undoubtedly to be tested in the light of the fundamental freedoms guaranteed by Ch. III of the Constitution. ... But it is not settled by decisions of this Court e.g. Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair, v. The State of Kerala

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxing statutes challengeable only if expropriatory or lacking procedure, not merely harsh/excessive; citing precedents.

holdings.text: Provisions of s. 280 and Sch. II are not discriminatory and do not infringe Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the scheme of annuity deposit makes an unlawful discrimination between taxpayers is also devoid of force. Article 14 of the Constitution guarantees equality before the law, and equal protection of the laws. But thereby the power of the Legislature

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification (income >Rs.15,000, progressive rates, age 70+ exemption) bears rational nexus to objectives of savings mobilisation and inflation control.

holdings.text: Pith and substance of Chapter XXII-A is taxes on income under Entry 82 List I, not borrowing.

anchor.surface_text: It is always necessary to examine the pith and substance of any law impugned on the ground of want of legislative competence with a view to ascertaining the precise entry in which it can come. The entries in the three Lists were intended to be exhaustive

holdings.reasoning_summary: Annuity deposit is alternative tax relief scheme using IT machinery; repayable instalments taxable on receipt.

holdings.text: Annuity deposit scheme is not borrowing under Article 292 as it is legislative tax deferral, not executive action on Consolidated Fund.

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that this is a case of borrowing which is defined in Art. 366(4) to include the raising of money by the grant of annuities, and loan is also required to be construed accordingly. ... Borrowing under that Article is by executive action

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes legislative tax scheme from executive borrowing; money returned with interest, taxable on refund.

holdings.text: Entry 97 List I is residuary power, to be invoked only as last resort after determining no specific entry applies.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. I agree that this petition should be dismissed with costs. I agree generally with the reasons given by my brother Shah, but I wish to say that I do not rest my decision on entry No. 97 of List I of the Seventh Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Caution against hasty reliance on residuary; first examine specific entries like 82.

holdings.text: Provisions neither colourable nor discriminatory; apply to upper income groups, defer tax on part of income.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions are neither colourable nor discriminatory. They apply to upper income groups and this does not lead to discrimination. They are not colourable because, though called annuity deposits, they only defer payment of tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Name immaterial; substance is tax deferral with interest.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ petition challenging the constitutional validity of Chapter XXII-A (annuity deposits) of the Income-tax Act, 1961 dismissed; provisions upheld as constitutional, within legislative competence, not colourable, not harsh/expropriatory, and not discriminatory under Article 14.
